short-title.#text:
Ethical Stem Cell Research Tax
			 Credit Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

header.#text:
Credit for
			 ethical stem cell research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding at the end the following new
			 section:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the
			 Internal Revenue Code of 1986

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in the case of an eligible
				taxpayer, the ethical stem cell research credit determined under this section
				for the taxable year shall be an amount equal to 30 percent of the qualified
				stem cell research expenses paid or incurred by the taxpayer during the taxable
				year.

text.#text: For purposes of

term.#tail:
means any taxpayer that elects the application of this section
				for the taxable year.

text.#text: For purposes of this section, the term
For purposes of this section—

term.#tail:
means expenses which are paid or incurred by the eligible
				taxpayer during the taxable year in carrying on basic and applied research to
				develop techniques for the isolation, derivation, production, testing, and
				human clinical use of stem cells that may result in improved understanding of
				or treatments for diseases and other adverse health conditions, no part of
				which may involve—

text.#text: The term

the creation of a
				human embryo for research purposes,

the destruction
				of or discarding of, or risk of injury to, a human embryo, or

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: or

text.#text:
the use of any
				stem cell, the derivation or provision of which would be inconsistent with

term.#tail:
means any organism not
				protected as a human subject under part 46 of title 45, Code of Federal
				Regulations (as in effect on the date of the enactment of this section) that is
				derived by fertilization, parthenogenesis, cloning, or any other means from one
				or more human gametes or human diploid cells.

text.#text: The term

means subjecting a
				human embryo to risk of injury or death greater than that allowed for research
				on a fetus in utero under

current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a
		  Federal income tax credit for certain stem cell research
		  expenditures.
